issues.description: The UML in the problem statement declares the attribute 'abbreviation' of Ride as type String (problem_statement.md), but the solution implementation uses a char field for abbreviation (solution Ride.java). This discrepancy affects the attribute type students are expected to declare and the type returned by the getter. Students will be instructed to create a constructor and getter matching the UML (String), but the reference solution and provided constructors use char, causing confusion and failing type-based tests.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the 'abbreviation' type consistent across all artifacts. Either change the UML and problem description to declare abbreviation: char, or (preferably to match the UML) change the solution and template implementations to use String for the abbreviation attribute, update constructors to accept String, and change the getter return types to String.

issues.description: The problem statement requires public constructors that take all attributes in the same order as in the UML (abbreviation declared as String). The solution constructors for Ride, RollerCoaster, LaunchedRollerCoaster and LaunchedDropdownTower use char for the abbreviation parameter. This is a constructor-parameter type mismatch versus the UML and task description and will cause students' constructors (if implemented per UML) to differ from the provided solution signatures.
issues.suggested_fix: Align constructor parameter types with the UML. Either update the UML to show abbreviation: char (and update the problem text) or update the solution/template constructors to accept String for abbreviation so they match the UML and task instructions.

issues.description: The getter for abbreviation in the solution returns char (getAbbreviation(): char), while the UML and problem description indicate abbreviation is a String. This causes a method return type mismatch between the specification and the solution implementation and will confuse students about the expected getter signature.
issues.suggested_fix: Ensure the getter return type matches the UML: if abbreviation is intended to be a String, change the Ride attribute to String and make getAbbreviation() return String. If abbreviation should be a char, update the UML and problem description to indicate abbreviation: char.
